review.title: A Note on Systematic Conflict Generation in CA-EN-type Causal Structures
review.abstract: This paper is aimed at providing a very first, more "global", systematic point of view with respect to possible conflict generation in CA-EN-like causal structures. For simplicity, only the outermost level of graphs is taken into account. Localization of the "conflict area", diagnostic preferences, and bases for systematic conflict generation are considered. A notion of {\em Potential Conflict Structure} ({\em PCS}) constituting a basic tool for identification of possible conflicts is proposed and its use is discussed.

sections.heading: 9 An Example
sections.text: A simple test program to support the direct determination of potential conflict structures has been implemented in PROLOG. The program is a meta-interpreter that uses several simple recursive rules. It calculates the potential conflict structures for a particular uncontrolled variable. An example subgraph of measured variables is shown in Fig. 6; potential conflicts calculated with the use of the program are also listed. Candidate variables for the heads of PCS should be preselected.

sections.heading: 10 Closing remarks
sections.text: From the above considerations, one can expect that the final efficiency of conflict (not diagnostic!) generation necessarily depends on a variety of factors. Furthermore, efficient conflicts, i.e. those that lead to a small number of well-localized diagnoses, can only be achieved if the variables that are not measured are relatively sparse. If there are only a few measurements, it cannot be expected that the isolation of faulty components will be effective. In relation to this problem, the reverse propagation seems to be a crucial problem - roughly speaking, it could play a similar role to the introduction of measurements and thus help to limit the size of conflicts. Another aspect that is worth investigating is the problem of faulty behavior of components and their influence on the observed behavior of variables; a priori knowledge of possible faults of components can be used to model the faulty behavior and thus select certain possible faults when the modeled behavior is not observed.
